statements.statementLabel: Can access all appropriately scaffolded learning being taught to the class group.
Can access all academic subjects with some additional differentiation/scaffolding.

Is ‘working towards’ expected level for the age in all areas of the curriculum. This could be due to specific difficulties in literacy or maths or general difficulties in all areas. They may also have some gaps in learning for a range of reasons.

Is up to 2 years out of step with peers (expected level according to teacher assessment). This could be due to specific difficulties in literacy or maths or general difficulties in all areas. They may also have considerable gaps in learning for a range of reasons.

Is over 2-3 years out of step with peers (expected level according to teacher assessment). This could be due to specific difficulties in literacy or maths or general difficulties in all areas. They may also have significant gaps in learning for a range of reasons.
Is over 3 years out of step with peers (expected level according to teacher assessment). This is due to a complex range of learning difficulties but also gaps in learning.
Has achieved or is working towards national examinations as appropriate for their age (GCSEs, NVQs, entry level qualifications). Is expected to pass/achieve these.
Needs to learn practically and visually in order to engage with and consolidate learning.
For a range of reasons (including learning, emotional needs), they need alternative options/pathways to a purely academic route across the week.
For a range of reasons (including learning and emotional), they cannot access academic/exam orientated courses. They can only access employment based or orientated learning.
For a range of reasons (including learning and emotional), they cannot access academic/exam orientated courses. They can only access life and functional skills work for example.
If focused and engaged, can process and understand most new learning presented to a level appropriate to his/her age.
If focused and engaged, can process and understand new learning presented with minor adjustments and scaffolding.

Has a processing speed that is slower than peers and finds it difficult to process information given at the same speed as others of their age. Understanding is then affected. If given some more time, answers he/she gives eventually are appropriate to the subject area.
Finds it difficult to process (understand) information even if given at a slower rate to peers or repeated.
Processing speed is very slow and this causes significant gaps in understanding. Finds it very difficult to keep up with others and then cannot understand the learning presented to the group.
Finds it difficult to process auditory information. Will pause and seem to be processing what has been said. Answers they give eventually are not always appropriate to the question asked.
Processing speed is very poor and they either gets lost in any new learning and/or disengages.
Despite good attention and focus, processing new or complex information is very difficult.
Makes some links in learning between subject areas and in different contexts (as expected for their age)
Processing speed is very slow and this causes significant gaps in understanding. Finds it very difficult to keep up with others and then cannot understand the learning presented to the group.
Finds it difficult to process auditory information. Will pause and seem to be processing what has been said. Answers they give eventually are not always appropriate to the question asked.
Has some 'theory of mind' to view the world from the perspective of others. Can put him/herself in other people's 'shoes'.
Does not instinctively attempt to view the world from other people's perspectives, but if reminded to think in this way, can come up with some ideas (however unusual).

Is mostly egocentric, viewing the world from their own perspective. If another's person's perspective is highlighted for them, they can usually understand this to some extent. They is interested in trying to do this.
Is mostly egocentric, viewing the world from their own perspective. If another person's perspective is highlighted for them, they cannot seem to understand this.This is a barrier to learning.
Cannot view situations from the perspective of others. Either is not interested in this, or wants to be able to, yet finds this frustrating and upsetting.
Is completely egocentric and has no 'theory of mind'. Does not know that others can experience the world differently from them and is not interested in this.
Will apply processing and problem solving skills needed to make safe choices and assess risk independently (to the level expected for his/her age).

Can understand simple right/wrong or safe/unsafe decision making processes. Can be quite 'all or nothing' in thinking and finds more sophisticated or unclear decision making harder to work through independently.

Will follow a series of rules and use these to stay safe for example. However when there are a range of alternative choices either with learning or in terms of safety, gets stuck with working out a way forward.
Has difficulties with the problem solving needed to stay safe eg who to talk to, risk assessing certain environments, making safe decisions.
Is at risk of harm if independently cooking, washing and cleaning due to lack of understanding of risk and limitations.
Shows curiosity and imagination, making links between different aspects of learning and questioning how things relate to each other in a cross-curricular way. Has good inference skills.
Notices some links in learning independently and has some inference skills. Does not always notice these but is seeking them out and interested in finding these links.
Makes some links/generalisations in learning but not consistently. Does not consistently apply inference skills to see patterns or consequences.
Does not make many links or generalisations in learning. Struggles to use inference skills consistently or accurately. Inability to use inference impacts on access to the curriculum.
Does not understand links or generalisations in learning even once explained to them. Inference skills are poor.
Can understand past present and future, and if told the time knows if this is morning, afternoon or evening (has a sense of time).
Can get momentarily confused about the tense and whether they are learning about/talking about past, present or future but either self-corrects or is easily reminded.
Finds it difficult to distinguish between past/present and future and this affects all decision making.
Does not have a good concept of time and hence any learning set in the past or future is confusing. Often cpnfuses tenses when speaking.
Any writing does not show use/understanding of tenses.
Has no sense of time, which impacts upon all learning. Can not understand if something is a past event or planned for the future.
Cannot give a view about what they want to happen in the future or what happened in the past.
No short term or working memory difficulties.
Some memory difficulties but with repetition can learn work schedules/routines etc.
Can remember short, simple instructions. However, if instructions are longer or more complicated they only remember part.
Finds it difficult to remember new learning across the span of a week.
Cannot hold more than two pieces of information in mind and work wth this information.
Finds it difficult to remember new learning by the next day.
Cannot hold more than one piece of information in mind and work with this information.
Does not retain new learning within the same lesson/day.
Numeracy skills are at the 'expected' level for their age. Has maths/numeracy skills that are sufficient to access other learning or the course they are on.
Has a few gaps in learning perhaps understanding of early concepts in maths but is not ‘stuck’. Is ‘working towards’ the level expected at his/her age.
Numeracy skills have not progressed at the expected rate despite initial group intervention (key stage 1 or 2). Maths/numeracy skills are about 2 years out of step with the expect level at their age.
Numeracy skills have not progressed at the expected rate despite individual targeted intervention. Maths/numeracy skills are 2-3 years out of step with the expected level at their age.
Is predicted to get less than a 4 in maths GCSE (Year 11+).

Numeracy skills are severely delayed and out of step with the expected level at their age, despite intervention. Maths/ numeracy skills difficulties are a barrier to them accessing other areas of the curriculum.
Has not achieved a level 4 or above at GCSE maths (Year 12+).
Has functional maths skills that enable him/her to understand and use money, budget, read timetables etc.
Needs support with maths/numeracy skills needed to access main course/programme.
Has significant gaps in understanding of functional skills required to understand and use money, budget, read timetables etc.
Does not have secure functional skills required to understand and use money, budget, read timetables etc.
Is working on access courses or functional skills courses for maths.
Literacy skills are at the expected level for their age. Literacy skills enable access to the wider curriculum.

Is ‘working towards’ the level expected at their age in reading and/or spelling. Has some gaps in learning perhaps relating to language needs or understanding of early concepts in literacy, but they are not ‘stuck’.

Has some difficulties at a word level with reading and/or spelling despite appropriate group intervention over time. Literacy difficulties are mild but impact upon access to areas of the curriculum which have a high demand on literacy skills.
Reading skills are just behind the level expected at their age but difficulties with reading comprehension are about 2 years out of step.

Reading and/or spelling skills have not progressed at the expected rate despite individual targeted intervention over time. Literacy difficulties are a barrier to learning across most areas of the curriculum to the extent that exam access arrangements are likely to be necessary. Is predicted to get less than a 4 in English GCSE (Year 11 +).
Reading/spelling skills have progressed with intervention however reading comprehension skills remain 2-3 years out of step.
Reading and/or spelling skills are severely delayed and out of step with chronological age and are a barrier across the curriculum. Has not achieved a level 4 or above at GCSE English (Y12 +)
They may or may not be able to decode text but with no understanding of what they are reading.

Has functional English skills that allow them to independently access lessons or courses and use skills in the community and for employment including: completing forms, sending emails and accessing information on the internet for example.
Has functional English skills but may need some support to access lessons, a course, programme or skills needed for life. This is usually due to fluency or accuracy.

Has gaps in functional skills using English, for example understanding and completing forms, emailing and accessing information via text. Gaps in literacy skills create barriers for them when accessing other curriculum areas.

Has poor functional skills using English, for example understanding and completing forms, emailing and accessing information via text. Gaps in literacy skills create signficant barriers for them when accessing other curriculum areas.

Has no functional skills using English, for example cannot independently understand and completing forms, emailing and accessing information via text. Literacy skills difficulties present them with barriers across the curriculm, in the community and in seeking employment.
Can use writing to record his/her thoughts and learning and keep up with the pace of peers in the lesson.
Is 'working towards' expected levels in writing. Can use writing to record his/her thoughts and is making some progress.
Makes some spelling errors but these are phonetically plausible or linked to homonyms. Can spell a range of high frequency words though fewer than same aged peers.
Finds it very difficult to organise thoughts in order to write. Cannot do this independently (of support or IT).
Is not making progress with spelling despite small group intervention over time. Spellings are not always phonetically plausible.
Reluctant to write and writing Is slow and not fluent. Will only write single words in a writing frame with additional prompting.

Significant difficulties with spelling despite intervention over time. These errors make it difficult for the reader to understand what is written. Spelling development is not following a typical pattern.
Will not write due to a range of reasons. Refuses to write and also finds it incredibly difficult.
